sections.html:
In order to extract a data table from one of the datasets, please proceed as follow:

  1. Select one of the 7 dataset (e.g. ‘UNDP adaptation learning mechanism’).
  2. Select the main field you want to explore (ex. ‘location’). The values that this field  (e.g. ‘rural’ or ‘urban’) will be used as the columns of the table.
  3. If the selected field contains too many values (e.g. the field ‘country’ contains the names of all the countries present in the dataset), select the values that interest you (otherwise the tool will select the 20 most frequent values[a]).
  4. Select as many secondary fields as you wish (e.g. ‘level of intervention’ and ‘hazards’). The values of the secondary fields will be used as rows of the table.
  5. If one or more of the secondary fields contains too many values, select the values that interest you (otherwise the tool will select the 20 most frequent values[b]).

In the example described, the resulting table will have 2 columns (‘rural’ or ‘urban’) and 14 rows ('community', 'municipality', 'district', 'regional', 'national', 'global' and ‘disease’, ‘drought/water scarcity’, ‘extreme weather events’, ‘flood’, ‘land degradation and deforestation’, ‘public health’, ‘sea level rise’, ‘wildfire’).

Each cell of the table will contain the number of projects tagged with the values of the corresponding column and row (e.g. ‘urban’ and ‘community’ or ‘local’ and ‘wildfire’). The content of the cell can also be switched to show the total amount of fund allocated to the relative projects.

To facilitate the visual comparison, the values of the cells are also presented as repetition of glyphs each of which represents 10 projects or 10 millions dollars[c].
